levels.1: Has heard of AI but cannot explain it accurately; relies on buzzwords or vague metaphors.
levels.2: Can describe AI at a high level using simple analogies but lacks understanding of how systems actually work.
levels.3: Understands basic concepts such as machine learning, LLMs, and prompts; aware AI can make mistakes.
levels.4: Understands training vs inference, context limits, and hallucinations; can explain typical strengths and weaknesses.
levels.5: Explains modern AI systems clearly (LLMs, embeddings, retrieval); understands trade-offs like accuracy, cost, and latency.
levels.6: Can diagnose common AI failures (prompt issues, data gaps, evaluation errors); explains AI clearly to non-technical audiences.
levels.7: Has strong intuition for where AI will or will not work; anticipates failure modes before deployment.
levels.8: Understands second-order effects (distribution shift, automation bias, feedback loops); challenges misuse confidently.
levels.9: Expert-level conceptual mastery; sets standards for AI understanding and usage across teams or organisations.

levels.1: Uses one-line prompts with inconsistent results; accepts poor outputs.
levels.2: Uses slightly longer prompts but with little structure or clarity of objective.
levels.3: Uses basic structure (role, task, format); can improve outputs through trial and error.
levels.4: Breaks problems into steps; specifies constraints and desired outputs.
levels.5: Creates reliable prompts with examples, formatting rules, and validation checks.
levels.6: Designs multi-step prompt flows; anticipates common edge cases and failure patterns.
levels.7: Creates reusable prompt patterns; coaches others on effective prompting techniques.
levels.8: Designs prompt systems with evaluation rubrics, self-checking, and consistency guarantees.
levels.9: Architects organisation-wide prompt standards and prompt-based systems at scale.

levels.1: Uses a single AI tool occasionally with no understanding of settings or limitations.
levels.2: Uses AI tools regularly but only in isolation (chat-only usage).
levels.3: Uses multiple AI tools for different tasks (chat, transcription, documents).
levels.4: Chooses appropriate tools for tasks; understands basic configuration options.
levels.5: Combines tools into simple workflows; understands APIs conceptually.
levels.6: Considers cost, latency, and reliability when selecting tools; can troubleshoot basic issues.
levels.7: Designs integrated AI toolchains; configures monitoring, QA, and fallback logic.
levels.8: Manages AI tooling strategically across teams; optimises cost/performance trade-offs.
levels.9: Designs and governs production-grade AI platforms with standards and controls.

levels.1: Accepts AI outputs at face value without questioning data sources.
levels.2: Aware that bad data can cause errors but unsure how to address it.
levels.3: Recognises bias, missing context, and outdated information as problems.
levels.4: Improves results by refining inputs and choosing better sources.
levels.5: Judges data relevance, quality, and recency; understands basic bias risks.
levels.6: Identifies data leakage and representativeness issues; proposes mitigations.
levels.7: Designs retrieval strategies and quality checks to improve AI outcomes.
levels.8: Defines data governance practices for AI workflows.
levels.9: Expert-level data judgment; sets organisation-wide data standards and controls.

levels.1: Uses AI manually for isolated tasks.
levels.2: Repeats similar AI tasks manually with minor variations.
levels.3: Creates simple templates or checklists for repeat use.
levels.4: Designs basic workflows linking inputs, AI steps, and outputs.
levels.5: Builds end-to-end workflows with human review and measurable impact.
levels.6: Identifies bottlenecks and improves workflow reliability.
levels.7: Scales workflows across teams with QA and exception handling.
levels.8: Continuously improves AI workflows using feedback and metrics.
levels.9: Architects enterprise-wide AI operating models and automation standards.

levels.1: Unaware or dismissive of AI risks.
levels.2: Aware AI can be wrong but often over-trusts outputs.
levels.3: Understands hallucinations and basic privacy risks.
levels.4: Applies simple safeguards such as verification and redaction.
levels.5: Designs practical controls for bias, IP, and misuse in workflows.
levels.6: Balances automation with human oversight appropriately.
levels.7: Designs governance, auditability, and escalation paths.
levels.8: Proactively manages AI risk across teams and use cases.
levels.9: Sets organisational AI ethics, risk policy, and compliance standards.

overall_interpretation_0_to_100.25-49: Developing practitioner with useful skills in defined contexts.
overall_interpretation_0_to_100.50-74: Strong AI-enabled operator capable of independent delivery.
overall_interpretation_0_to_100.75-100: AI-native leader capable of designing and scaling AI systems responsibly.
